prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We select a high spectral resolution in the band spanning the CO(1-0) line, allowing us to resolve narrow, strong lines, or rebin to lower spectral resolution as required for weaker lines. The lowest resolution continuum mode is unsuitable given the ~100 km/s linewidth expected as each line would only occupy one channel. We select the broadest possible baseband in order to measure any velocity offset between different gas components, or between the molecular gas and the systemic stellar/nebular emission component redshift. This constrains us to a single choice of correlator configuration.
We set additional subbands to maximise our sensitivity to continuum emission, using the lowest resolution setting. However we do not set a sensitivity goal with this in mind, and would consider it highly desirable auxilliary data rather than key to our experiment.

All our sources are essentially unresolved in SDSS optical imaging (at ~1.3 arcsecond seeing). Our 21cm imaging of these targets suggest that they are more compact still, remaining unresolved at sub-arcsecond scales.
Given their relatively modest masses and comparison samples with similar (although distinct) properties, we would expect them to have a very compact mass distribution, with most components below 0.5 arcseconds, but would be unsurprised if a subset of these sources show multiple components, or distorted morphologies, indicative of merging. Assessing this merger fraction is part of our science targets, however this will not be possible in the CO(1-0) line. In band 3, we select an angular resolution of 0.4 arcseconds, sufficient to prevent any ambiguity in alignment or identification with sub-arcsec optical and radio counterparts, and sufficient to identify any significant extension of the targets (likely due to multiple, blended components).

We have no prior knowledge of the carbon monoxide line strength in these sources. WISE detections and optial-nearIR SED fitting suggest that they are moderately massive galaxies (M(stars)~10^9.5 Msun), with a non-negligible amount of dust (E(B-V)~0.2). We extrapolate from the stellar mass and assume that these have a mass to light ratio close to 1 (comparable to other star forming galaxies). This gives us an inferred (although uncertain) far infrared luminosity, from which we use the close linear correlation given by Solomon and vanden Bout (2005) to infer an estimated CO(1-0) luminosity.
Acknowledging the rather large uncertainties on each step of this process, we target an unambiguous detection at this level, while allowing ourselves room for a lower signal to noise detection if this population is somewhat below the usual L_FIR-L_CO relation. We thus aim to secure a signal to noise of ~8 on the peak of the line emission in each target, measured in a third of the line FWHM, giving us several independent channels across the line width each exceeding ~5 sigma. In the event that the line is above the standard relations, this resolution will enable us to constrain the line width (and hence dynamical mass to a fraction of the 25 km/s typical channel resolution. If the line is fainter than we expect, we will still be able to smooth and rebin to a lower spectral resolution, recovering a detection on the integrated line flux, rather than multiple detections or a line profile.
We select galaxies in a narrow band of redshift, in order to provide a uniform depth sample, rather than dealing with variation in evolutionary state, metallicity, conversion factor evolution etc over an extended redshift range. This gives us a sample of 12 sources which will provide a valuable insight into the larger population. It will allow us to evaluate the feasibility and desireability of exploring a larger sample in future, while still spanning the full range of ultraviolet and optical luminosities in this population, and represents a publishable unit without further observations.
We do not know the line width, therefore we adopt a standard estimate of 100 km/s, as seen in other targets of comparable mass. We note that we would still recover narrower lines, and that this uncertainty drives our choice of correlator configuration.

All our sources are essentially unresolved in SDSS optical imaging (at ~1.3 arcsecond seeing). Our 21cm imaging of these targets suggest that they are more compact still, remaining unresolved at sub-arcsecond scales.
Given their relatively modest masses and comparison samples with similar (although distinct) properties, we would expect them to have a very compact mass distribution, with most components below 0.5 arcseconds, but would be unsurprised if a subset of these sources show multiple components, or distorted morphologies, indicative of merging. Assessing this merger fraction is part of our science targets, however this will not be possible in the CO(1-0) line. In band 8, we select an angular resolution of 0.1 arcseconds, sufficient to resolve regions comparable in size to known sources of identical physical properties (such as LBGs at z=5, Oesch et al 2009) and also similar low mass galaxy populations previously observed with Hubble (e.g. the ultraviolet-luminous galaxies of Heckman et al 2005). This is also sufficient to prevent any ambiguity in alignment or identification with sub-arcsec optical and radio counterparts, and to identify any significant extension of the targets (likely due to sub-resolution element-scale, blended components).

We have no prior knowledge of the carbon monoxide line strength in these sources. WISE detections and optial-nearIR SED fitting suggest that they are moderately massive galaxies (M(stars)~10^9.5 Msun), with a non-negligible amount of dust (E(B-V)~0.2). This gives us an inferred (although uncertain) far infrared luminosity, from which we use the close linear correlation given by Solomon and vanden Bout (2005) to infer an estimated CO(1-0) luminosity. To convert from the CO(1-0) prediction to a CO(4-3) prediction in band 8, we assume an excitation ladder intermediate between that observed in the Milky Way and examples of local ULIRG type systems. We assume that the excitation is subthermal (by ~50%) yielding a CO(4-3)/CO(1-0) flux ratio of 7.

We extrapolate from the stellar mass and assume that these have a mass to light ratio close to 1 (comparable to other star forming galaxies). This gives us an inferred (although uncertain) far infrared luminosity, from which we use the close linear correlation given by Solomon and vanden Bout (2005) to infer an estimated CO(1-0) luminosity. To convert from the CO(1-0) prediction to a CO(4-3) prediction in band 8, we assume an excitation ladder intermediate between that observed in the Milky Way and examples of local ULIRG type systems. We assume that the excitation is subthermal (by ~50%) yielding a CO(4-3)/CO(1-0) flux ratio of 7.
Acknowledging the rather large uncertainties on each step of this process, we target an unambiguous detection at this level, while allowing ourselves room for a lower signal to noise detection if this population is somewhat below the usual L_FIR-L_CO relation. We thus aim to secure a signal to noise of ~8 on the peak of the line emission in each target, measured in a third of the line FWHM, giving us several independent channels across the line width each exceeding ~5 sigma. In the event that the line is above the standard relations, this resolution will enable us to constrain the line width (and hence dynamical mass to a fraction of the 25 km/s typical channel resolution. If the line is fainter than we expect, we will still be able to smooth and rebin to a lower spectral resolution, recovering a detection on the integrated line flux, rather than multiple detections or a line profile.
We select galaxies in a narrow band of redshift, in order to provide a uniform depth sample, rather than dealing with variation in evolutionary state, metallicity, conversion factor evolution etc over an extended redshift range. This gives us a sample of 12 sources which will provide a valuable insight into the larger population. It will allow us to evaluate the feasibility and desireability of exploring a larger sample in future, while still spanning the full range of ultraviolet and optical luminosities in this population, and represents a publishable unit without further observations.
We do not know the line width, therefore we adopt a standard estimate of 100 km/s, as seen in other targets of comparable mass. We note that we would still recover narrower lines, and that this uncertainty drives our choice of correlator configuration.

We select a high spectral resolution in the band spanning the CO(1-0) line, allowing us to resolve narrow, strong lines, or rebin to lower spectral resolution as required for weaker lines. The lowest resolution continuum mode is unsuitable given the ~100 km/s linewidth expected as each line would only occupy one channel. We select the broadest possible baseband in order to measure any velocity offset between different gas components, or between the molecular gas and the systemic stellar/nebular emission component redshift. This constrains us to a single choice of correlator configuration.
We set additional subbands to maximise our sensitivity to continuum emission, using the lowest resolution setting. However we do not set a sensitivity goal with this in mind, and would consider it highly desirable auxilliary data rather than key to our experiment.

All our sources are essentially unresolved in SDSS optical imaging (at ~1.3 arcsecond seeing). Our 21cm imaging of these targets suggest that they are more compact still, remaining unresolved at sub-arcsecond scales.
Given their relatively modest masses and comparison samples with similar (although distinct) properties, we would expect them to have a very compact mass distribution, with most components below 0.5 arcseconds, but would be unsurprised if a subset of these sources show multiple components, or distorted morphologies, indicative of merging. Assessing this merger fraction is part of our science targets, however this will not be possible in the CO(1-0) line. In band 3, we select an angular resolution of 0.4 arcseconds, sufficient to prevent any ambiguity in alignment or identification with sub-arcsec optical and radio counterparts, and sufficient to identify any significant extension of the targets (likely due to multiple, blended components).

This constrains us to a single choice of correlator configuration.
We set additional subbands to maximise our sensitivity to continuum emission, using the lowest resolution setting. However we do not set a sensitivity goal with this in mind, and would consider it highly desirable auxilliary data rather than key to our experiment.

All our sources are essentially unresolved in SDSS optical imaging (at ~1.3 arcsecond seeing). Our 21cm imaging of these targets suggest that they are more compact still, remaining unresolved at sub-arcsecond scales.
Given their relatively modest masses and comparison samples with similar (although distinct) properties, we would expect them to have a very compact mass distribution, with most components below 0.5 arcseconds, but would be unsurprised if a subset of these sources show multiple components, or distorted morphologies, indicative of merging. Assessing this merger fraction is part of our science targets, however this will not be possible in the CO(1-0) line. In band 3, we select an angular resolution of 0.4 arcseconds, sufficient to prevent any ambiguity in alignment or identification with sub-arcsec optical and radio counterparts, and sufficient to identify any significant extension of the targets (likely due to multiple, blended components).

We have no prior knowledge of the carbon monoxide line strength in these sources. WISE detections and optial-nearIR SED fitting suggest that they are moderately massive galaxies (M(stars)~10^9.5 Msun), with a non-negligible amount of dust (E(B-V)~0.2). We extrapolate from the stellar mass and assume that these have a mass to light ratio close to 1 (comparable to other star forming galaxies). This gives us an inferred (although uncertain) far infrared luminosity, from which we use the close linear correlation given by Solomon and vanden Bout (2005) to infer an estimated CO(1-0) luminosity.
Acknowledging the rather large uncertainties on each step of this process, we target an unambiguous detection at this level, while allowing ourselves room for a lower signal to noise detection if this population is somewhat below the usual L_FIR-L_CO relation. We thus aim to secure a signal to noise of ~8 on the peak of the line emission in each target, measured in a third of the line FWHM, giving us several independent channels across the line width each exceeding ~5 sigma. In the event that the line is above the standard relations, this resolution will enable us to constrain the line width (and hence dynamical mass to a fraction of the 25 km/s typical channel resolution. If the line is fainter than we expect, we will still be able to smooth and rebin to a lower spectral resolution, recovering a detection on the integrated line flux, rather than multiple detections or a line profile.
We select galaxies in a narrow band of redshift, in order to provide a uniform depth sample, rather than dealing with variation in evolutionary state, metallicity, conversion factor evolution etc over an extended redshift range. This gives us a sample of 12 sources which will provide a valuable insight into the larger population. It will allow us to evaluate the feasibility and desireability of exploring a larger sample in future, while still spanning the full range of ultraviolet and optical luminosities in this population, and represents a publishable unit without further observations.
We do not know the line width, therefore we adopt a standard estimate of 100 km/s, as seen in other targets of comparable mass. We note that we would still recover narrower lines, and that this uncertainty drives our choice of correlator configuration.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe a sample of 12 local star-forming galaxies selected to match the properties of z~5 Lyman break galaxies. These Lyman break analogues offer an opportunity to explore the molecular gas properities in a physical environment comparable to that in high redshift systems. Their low redshifts make accessible observations which would be impossible in the early Universe. Through obervations of two CO rotational excitation lines (CO(1-0) in band 3, and CO(4-3) in band 8) we will be able to determine the gas temperature, gas dynamics, and carbon monoxide gas mass. This will also allow us to infer the molecular hydrogen mass present in these systems, and hence the gas depletion timescale associated with ongoing star formation. High resolution observations will map the morphology of these galaxies, to evaluate the merger or multi-component fraction in the sample. These observations will refine our understanding of the origin and nature of star formation in such objects.
